Archived Provost information

 

Provost and Executive Vice President

 

Letters Straight from the Provost (Archived - no longer current)

Please reference the current Provost page.

2024

Dear Colleagues,

President Seidel informed me last Friday that he needs to make a change in the Provost position.  I respect his decision and will end my appointment at the close of business today.  I look forward to joining my colleagues in Zoology & Physiology as a faculty member.

It has been an honor and a privilege to serve as UW’s Provost over the past 3.5 years.  We have faced many challenges and done many good things.  I am particularly pleased with the good work we have done to promote student success.

I am most grateful for the wonderful faculty, staff, students, and administrators with whom I have had the opportunity to work.  I’m sure that you will give my successor the same generous support that you provided to me.  Collectively, you make UW the wonderful institution that it is.

Please know that the Vice Provosts and our staff in the Provost’s Office remain committed to providing high-quality service and support to our faculty, staff, students, and administrators. You can continue to send inquiries and requests to provost@uwyo.edu.

Go Pokes!

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

One of my favorite times of the year is during the fall semester when we recognize faculty receiving tenure, fixed-term rolling contracts, and promotion. This evening, I am honored to be reading the names of over 50 of our colleagues that achieved these accomplishments this year. I look forward to celebrating with them!

The Board of Trustees have been meeting this week and if you haven’t tuned in, I would encourage you to listen or watch this one. There have been topics that are very important to campus, such as the recent results on the firearms survey, updates from President Seidel on our strategic plan, and strategies on enrollment. All these topics impact faculty, students, and staff at UW. Stay informed by finding links to the recordings here. 

Once again, a highlight of my week was meeting students for coffee on Monday. I was able to have great chats with Josiah Hanly and Carson Krueger.  Josiah is from Grand Junction, CO and Carson is from Laramie.  They are both remarkably mature and impressive young scholars.

A shout-out this week to Dr. Nikolas Sweet in Anthropology, who was recently selected as one of four inaugural Norman G. Pauling Early Career Research Fellows. This prestigious award is administered nationally by Phi Beta Kappa.  Nik will receive funding to support his project entitled “Gun Culture and Hunting: Perspectives from Linguistic Anthropology”. Congrats, Nik!

I will close by announcing that our search committee has selected finalists for the Vice Provost for Undergraduate position. Congratulations to Dr. Michelle Hillarie, and Dr. Eric Wodahl as they progress in the process. More to come as we begin to schedule their on campus presentations in the coming week.  

Go Pokes! 

Cheers, 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

On Monday I attended the celebration and discussion of a book project titled "Polarization and Deep Contestations: The Liberal Script in the United States." The book is a collaborative effort between colleagues from the Free University of Berlin – Drs. Tanja Borzel and Thomas Risse – and our own Drs. Jean Garrison and Stephanie Anderson.  Drs. Peter Parolin and Andrew Garner also authored chapters in the book. This type of project is an excellent example of the importance of internationalization and collaboration in higher education. 

If you missed the University of Wyoming "State of the University" address this past Tuesday, you can watch the recording here. There are many things to be proud of about our institution, and good things to come. I was impressed with the turnout of faculty and staff and appreciated the time to speak.

Nominations are being solicited for our student speaker for the Winter Commencement Ceremony on December 14. Faculty, staff, and student organizations are invited to nominate students for this incredible honor. We are looking for students with a record of academic excellence, demonstrated leadership, and excellent presentation skills. To submit a nomination, see the link here. 

Academic Affairs is proud to have selected two colleagues to attend the Academic Management Institute (AMI) leadership development series. Congratulations to Chicory Bechtel, Associate Director for the Office of Community Engagement, and Melanie Vigil, Assistant Dean of Students. 

The Board of Trustees meets next week in Laramie, and it is a very full agenda. To see the materials for the meeting, that starts with committee meetings on Wednesday, see the link here. 

The highlight of my week was having lunch at Rendezvous with two of our new students, Haley Cranwell from Hays, KS, and Christopher Mongar from Casper.  They are simply remarkable young people.  Our conversation was so engaging that I lost track of time and had to double-time it back to Old Main for my 1 pm meeting. 

Enjoy the weekend, 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

Yesterday, I met with the Next Gen USP (University Studies Program) Executive Committee to wrap up discussions and final revisions on the Next Gen USP model. I'm very pleased with the progress that has been made and am looking forward to presenting the proposed USP to the UW community in the coming weeks and getting your feedback. After incorporating feedback from campus constituents, we will work with the Faculty Senate to finalize the model.

I hope to see you all at the University of Wyoming "State of the University" address next Tuesday, September 17, from 3:30-5pm in the Union Center and West Ballrooms. I look forward to providing a brief report on initiatives in Academic Affairs before President Seidel takes the stage for his remarks.  Please join us at Pokes Pub following the address. If you prefer to join on WyoCast the link can be found here.

Also on Tuesday next week, UW will celebrate Constitution Day, which you can learn more about here. A highlight of the program will be on Wednesday when free speech icon Mary Beth Tinker visits campus for a conversation hosted by UW's Malcom Wallop Civic Engagement Program and the School of Politics, Public Affairs and International Studies. 

I’m pleased to share that we received 9 applicants for the Vice Provost for Undergraduate Education.  The search committee met today and reviewed the applications.  They will be conducting initial interviews beginning next week after which we will announce the finalists.  We plan to ask finalists to give a public presentation to share their vision for the position, and we will provide an opportunity for feedback from the UW community.

Finally, Vice President for Information Technology, Robert Aylward, has announced his plans to retire on November 25 of this year. Robert began his UW employment in 1978 as a student worker and, aside from a 4-year stint with MCI, has served UW more or less continuously since then.  Phil Dubois appointed Robert as interim VP for IT in 1997 then as the permanent VP in 1998.  27 years as a vice president has to be some kind fgtof record!  Robert is broadly respected, admired, and liked.  We will miss him greatly and I’m sure you will join me in wishing him every success and happiness in his next chapter. 

Enjoy the weekend, 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

Congratulations to John Koprowski, for his reappointment as Dean of the Haub School of Environment and Natural Resources. John has been an impactful leader and great colleague and I'm glad he will stay with us for (at least) another term. I'd also like to welcome Dr. Narina Nunez as our Interim Ombudsperson. Narina is stepping in to fill a critical role while we search for the next UW Ombuds. I know Narina is deeply respected and is well-known in our campus community. I'm grateful she has come out of retirement to support the UW community. 

As you know, we are currently searching for the next Dean of the College of Health Sciences. The search committee met earlier this week to discuss the upcoming interview process. Currently, there are over 50 candidates who have applied, and applications are being accepted until tomorrow (Friday). A large pool of candidates is a great challenge to have, and I have every confidence the search committee will identify a strong group of finalists. 

Finally, I'd like to thank Vice Provost Steve Barrett, Erika Helgeson, and Rick Fisher for their incredible work drafting our Higher Learning Commission (HLC) mid-cycle accreditation report. The external review team was very complimentary of UW across the board.  Today we received a letter from the HLC confirming that our review process has been successfully completed.  We owe these three colleagues our gratitude for pulling it all together. 

Enjoy the weekend and Go Pokes!  

Cheers, 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

I hope you enjoy seeing students back on campus as much as I do.  It's always nice to see Prexy's buzzing with activity. 

Two gentle reminders before some updates.  Our Faculty Affairs team will be providing an informational session on reappointment, tenure, promotion, and fixed-term rolling contract reviews on September 5th from noon to 12:50 pm.  All faculty and academic administrators are welcome to attend, but I especially encourage faculty who will be going through one of these reviews this year or next year to attend.  The session will be held via Zoom.  To join, please use the ZOOM ID: 91332799986

A final reminder this week about our search for the next Vice Provost for Undergraduate Education. A full position description can be found here, and the application deadline is tomorrow (Friday) at noon. Internal applicants should submit a single PDF document that contains: 1) a letter of interest describing relevant experience, 2) a current curriculum vitae, and 3) name and contact information of three (3) references to provost@uwyo.edu. 

I'm sure your inboxes have been deluged, but there are important items I want to bring to your attention. Last week, a campus communication announced a survey being conducted to get input on concealed weapons on campus as part of a directive from Governor Mark Gordon.  The results could influence the direction that UW takes on this issue. Please take a moment to express your thoughts about our current regulation, and potential changes to the regulation here. 

Also announced last week were updates regarding the Administration and Board of Trustees' actions in response to the Wyoming legislature’s mandate to eliminate the DEI office. President Seidel presented the DEI Working Group report to the Board of Trustees in May, and from that report, a definition of DEI was officially adopted for our institution which has resulted in a new policy titled "Equal Opportunity and Prohibited Efforts". You can view the policy here, and related FAQs here. We understand that there may be confusion as this new policy gets implemented.  Please be patient as we all try to navigate the complexities.  

We will, of course, continue to obey the law regarding DEI and modify our programs and structure as needed.  Our compliance with Wyoming legislative mandate regarding DEI makes it especially important for all of us, individually and collectively, to redouble our commitment to our diverse community with an understanding that those who look, love, and believe differently than we do need our support and understanding more than ever.   

Regards,  
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

This week, we welcomed 90 new faculty to our campus. I was delighted to attend the New Faculty Orientation on Tuesday to welcome this great cohort of colleagues. I'd like to thank our incredible AA team of Tami, Paige, Stephanie, Cheri, and Nini for organizing this event. 

Yesterday, I attended a few classes in our Saddle Up program. I was very impressed with the engagement between students and professors and enjoyed the lectures. Thanks to Kent Drummond, John Willford, and Matt Gray for giving their time this week to participate in Saddle Up! 

I have also had the opportunity to meet and visit with several Saddle Up participants and Poke Pack leaders throughout the week.  They are remarkable young people and truly inspirational.  Many thanks to Abby Markley, Nycole Courtney, and the entire Student Success and Graduation team for orchestrating another successful onboarding experience for the newest members of the UW student community. The photo below is of Poke Pack 141:


 

Our friends in Information Technology (IT), have scheduled AI-related trainings for this fall. If you are interested in learning about AI Companion on ZOOM, or Microsoft 365 Copilot AI, you can register here. 

Another exciting opportunity to be engaged with AI is through a matching fund with the state legislature in building artificial intelligence expertise. Angela Ver Ploeg from the Office of Industry and Strategic Partnerships presented to the Deans Council this week and is working with Deans to identify faculty and programs doing AI work to be considered for this funding. If you are interested, contact your dean or director. 

Our Faculty Affairs team will be providing an informational session on reappointment, tenure, promotion, and fixed-term rolling contract reviews on September 5th from noon to 12:50 pm.  All faculty and academic administrators are welcome to attend, but I especially encourage faculty who will be going through one of these reviews this year or next year to attend.  The session will be held via Zoom.  To join, please use the ZOOM ID: 91332799986

Today is the official return date for all returning faculty. I hope you all had a wonderful summer and are refreshed and excited for the fall semester. See you around soon!

Cheers, 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

P.S. In case you missed some recent messages, here's a snapshot of important items which can be found archived on the AA website here:

The search for the next Vice Provost for Undergraduate Education is underway. 
Work with your department head on low-enrollment waivers. 
Dr. Brandon McElroy is the new Vice Provost for Access and Engagement.

Dear Colleagues,

This morning, my office sent a reminder to department heads/chairs with this fall's low-enrollment course procedures. We are asking faculty/instructors/department heads to work with advising managers to send targeted messages to encourage categories or cohorts of students to enroll in the course if it is under the enrollment minimum. Procedures for requesting a waiver/canceling the course can be found here. Our colleagues in the Office of Institutional Analysis and the Registrar have developed course-enrollment reports that you can find here. Thanks for your attention to this. 

UW Libraries is streamlining course reserves and readings with a new tool, Leganto, now integrated with WyoCourses as "Readings and Resources”. This tool allows instructors to create lists of content including library materials and resources from other platforms like YouTube. It provides quick access for students to readings and more directly from Canvas. You can read more about implementing Readings and Resources into your WyoCourses here. 

I'm sending a reminder this week about our search for the next Vice Provost for Undergraduate Education. A full position description can be found here, and the application deadline is noon, August 30, 2024. Internal applicants should submit a single PDF document that contains: 1) a letter of interest describing relevant experience, 2) a current curriculum vitae, and 3) name and contact information of three (3) references to provost@uwyo.edu. 

Here they come! Around 1200 freshman will move into the dorms tomorrow as they prepare to engage next week in Saddle Up, which will celebrate its third year. This should be the year when the program really hits its stride as we have had two years to work out the kinks, and we have over 160 Poke Pack Leaders who have participated in the program and can provide leadership guided by direct experience.  I will be helping with the student move-in tomorrow during my shift from 9-11am. I'll be working the cart station, so stop by and say hello  

Cheers, 
 

 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

The search for the next Vice Provost for Undergraduate Education is officially launching today. I invite applications from internal candidates who can provide strong and visionary leadership to support our undergraduate programs. A full position description can be found here, and the application deadline is noon, August 30, 2024. Applicants should submit a single PDF document that contains: 1) a letter of interest describing relevant experience, 2) a current curriculum vitae, and 3) name and contact information of three (3) references to provost@uwyo.edu. I will announce the finalists and the campus interview schedules in September. 

UW Communication Across the Curriculum (CxC) recently wrapped the fourth year of its Academic Writing Fellows program, which is designed to support increased productivity and quality of UW scholars’ publication efforts.  During these four years, approximately 40 fellows have produced nearly 200 scholarly works (articles, book chapters, proposals, and other publications).  The program (which will be co-faciliated by past participant April French) is now accepting applications for its fifth year.  Questions about the program can be sent to CxC Director Rick Fisher at rick.fisher@uwyo.edu.  Applications are due Wednesday, September 5, 2024.

As you may have seen from the campus communication today, I am co-chairing the President's Budget Model Review Working Group, which is charged with developing a university-wide budget model that will incentivize and reward growth. I am committed to a clear and transparent process regarding any changes recommended by this working group and I assure you that there will be ample opportunity for UW input into any proposed changes. 

As I mentioned last week, I attended the Lamborn-Hughes retreat at CSU this week.  Several universities spent 2.5 days focusing on a particular “student success” challenge for their institution.  Our team (consisting of folks from Student Affairs, Academic Affairs, and Budget and Finance) focused on UW’s approach to managing academic probation, with an eye towards being more supportive of students who face academic challenges.  We came away with several concrete challenges, which we will be bringing to the UW community this fall for consideration. 

Cheers, 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

I'd like to welcome Dr. Brandon McElroy to the Academic Affairs team as the new Vice Provost for Access and Engagement. Brandon is a professor in the Department of Geology and Geophysics and he served on the DEI Review Working Group this past spring. Brandon will be working over the next year on establishing plans for transitioning critical functions that were previously managed by the Office of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion. Brandon has some important work ahead, and I'm thrilled he has taken on this role. 

This week, we say goodbye to Nellie Haddad, UW's Ombudsperson. Nellie started on campus last spring and helped launch the Office of the Ombuds. While the search will begin soon for a replacement, be looking for an announcement next week about an interim ombudsperson that will help keep the office open and assist with the transition. Best of luck in your next chapter, Nellie.

I'd like to give a shout-out to our Strook Chair and distinguished environmental economist, Jay Shogren, who has been recognized as the #2 environmental economist for 2022 (see article here). Jay also recently accepted a Presidential Fellowship to advance economic development opportunities of the creative economy, and will be working specifically with Beth Venn, executive director of UW's Neltje Center. Congrats, Jay.

Looking ahead to next week, I will be attending a two-and-a-half-day workshop at CSU with several members of our Academic Affairs and Student Affairs teams to do a deep dive regarding best practices in promoting student success. Six other universities, including CSU, the University of Texas at Austin, and the University of Pittsburgh will be participating in the workshop.  I will provide an update in the coming weeks as we work on efforts here at UW. 

I’m pleased to announce that Nini Gegidze will be joining our Academic Affairs team on Monday.  She will be filling the Program Coordinator position previously held by Kaylin Brooks. If you are in the vicinity of Old Main, please stop in and welcome her. 

All best wishes, 
 

 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

This week, I finalized the search committee for the next Vice Provost for Undergraduate Education. The committee will meet soon and expect to send out an announcement with details about the application process within the next two weeks. This will be an internal search at UW, and finalists will have campus interviews and public presentations. Thank you to Vice Provost Matt Griswold for chairing the search and the following colleagues for contributing their time as search committee members: 

  • Jim Ahern
  • Tami Benham Deal
  • April Heaney 
  • Erika Helgeson
  • Kyle Moore
  • Carolyn Pepper 
  • Brent Pickett
  • Ronn Smith

I'd also like to mention that I have identified an individual who is willing to serve as the new Vice Provost for Access and Engagement and hope to share further information with you in early August.

On August 13th, the Campus Safety Working Group will meet to discuss safety concerns on campus and prioritize addressing any identified safety risks. If you have any areas of concern that you would like the working group to review, please send me a note at provost@uwyo.edu. It's a priority to keep our campus safe, and we need everyone's help to keep it that way. 

I'd like to welcome Whit Madere to the UW team. Whit recently accepted the position of Internal Auditor. Whit brings extensive experience as an auditor in higher education.  Auditing our internal processes and procedures is important and provides opportunities to identify issues and create efficiencies in our work. Welcome to UW, Whit, we look forward to working with you.  

I appreciated the opportunity to join Adam Comeau and the Staff Senate at their retreat earlier this week.  I especially enjoyed the opportunity to visit with Senators Ann Roberson and Tanya Wheeler over lunch.

Finally, the start of the fall semester is creeping up on us. Vice Provost for Graduate Education, Jim Ahern, recently sent out a note to colleges that we have a continued issue of late registration with our graduate student population. Late registration can create many unnecessary problems and delays, so please work with your grad students to get them registered for fall classes. 

Thanks for all you do, and have a great weekend.  

Cheers,  
 

Dear Colleagues,

This week, I'm attending the Board of Trustees meeting at the Neltje Center in Sheridan.  The meeting started yesterday with a robust discussion with some members of our state legislature. The discussion covered many topics including the value of higher education, how the university is tending to the needs of the state, and the university's response to the recent legislative footnote on DEI. It was a very productive and overall positive conversation. If you would like to listen to that portion of the meeting, you can view it on WyoCast here. 

The topics covered today range from tuition, scholarships, financial aid, and fundraising. However, the bulk of the discussion will be focused on enrollment. As we know, high school graduation rates and enrollment in higher-education institutions have declined in recent years, and Wyoming and UW are no exception. There has also been a significant negative shift in the perceived value proposition of higher education. How we approach these issues will be critical to the future of the University of Wyoming. I have every confidence that UW can make strategic changes that will increase the value and experience at our great university. 

A few areas that we already have begun working on are a financial literacy program, career development, and growing certificate programs. Areas that we will work on in the coming months include investing in recruitment of new students, increased attention on students who stop-out or are on academic recovery, growing online and continuing education programs, increasing enrollment of international students, and overall student success initiatives to enhance student retention. We are also working with community colleges to improve our processes for helping students transition to UW.  As we work on enrollment at UW, I want to emphasize that this impacts all of us and will take a collective effort to change the tide.

Cheyenne Frontier Days is happening now, so I will be at the rodeo on Sunday watching the chutes. Enjoy the weekend. 

Cheers,  
 

 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

We are at a critical point just before the fall semester in helping our students prepare for courses. If you are teaching this fall and have not submitted your textbook requests to the University Store, please take a few moments to wrap this up. You can find a link to submit materials here. 

As you know, for the past year we have been working with Dr. Lewis (Lew) Sanborne, a lead representative from Ruffalo Noel Levitz (RNL) to assist with developing a Strategic Enrollment Plan (SEP) for UW.  Dr. Sanborn has been on campus this week meeting with President Seidel and me, as well as a new working group charged with implementing the SEP. Our great team will be working hard during the coming year to facilitate the implementation of strategies outlined in the plan.  I'd like to thank Kyle Moore and Nycole Courtney for leading this effort. More to come on this in the coming months. 

I'm pleased to announce that Dr. David Bagley, Professor and Associate Dean in the College of Engineering and Physical Sciences, has accepted my offer to serve as the next Vice Provost for Faculty Affairs. Dr. Bagley will be shadowing Tami during the fall semester and will begin his appointment full time in January 2025.   

I am currently reviewing the undergraduate classes taught at UW during the 2023-24 academic year with a particular focus on under-enrolled sections and classes with concerning DFW patterns.  For example, out of 3200 class sections that were taught last year, approximately 800 of them were below the enrollment minimum of 10 students.  I’ll be working closely with deans to strategically identify opportunities for efficiencies in fulfilling our teaching mission while being mindful of providing the courses that our students need.

I'm heading to the APLU Council on Academic Affairs summer meeting in Ohio early next week. The main topics for the conference include the value proposition of higher education, supporting mental health of faculty and staff, and preparing students for the 21st century workforce. All these topics are very relevant at UW, and I look forward to hearing from fellow Provosts on these topics. 

Looks like a warm weekend coming up in Laradise, enjoy the sun. 

Regards,  
 

 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

This week has been heavily focused on preparation for the Board of Trustees July meeting. There will be a significant amount of time spent on UW's strategic enrollment plan, where we discuss a long-term vision for enrollment. This plan will include many facets such as recruitment, retention, marketing, online programs, etc. The agenda and materials will be available on the Trustees website soon, and I encourage you to tune in and listen via WyoCast. 

As you may know, there has been an increase in disability service accommodations for our students, especially since the pandemic. While it is good to see more recognition and acknowledgement of the increased need, it has encouraged us to look at our own practices and support systems.  Our Disability Support Services (DSS) has been working hard to balance the increase of accommodation requests with the need to provide a more streamlined process for students and faculty. Beginning this fall, DSS will launch the new Accessibility Information Management (AIM) Portal to help monitor accommodation requests. This new system will give students better access to their information and will also provide faculty a process to view information about their courses, students with accommodations, and accurate test information for proctoring exams. More information will be coming soon to faculty and students, and I look forward to seeing the results of the new process and system. 

My office has been engaged in two Vice Provost searches these past couple of weeks. We have candidates for the Vice Provost for Faculty Affairs and the Vice Provost for Access and Engagement positions and are working through the final stages of meetings with finalists. I hope to provide a more substantive announcement soon.

One more critical announcement this week. Dr. Steve Barrett will return to the College of Engineering and Physical Sciences as the Associate Dean for Undergraduate Programs on September 30th of this year. Steve has served as Vice Provost for Undergraduate Education for four years and has been an outstanding colleague. I know Steve will be incredibly helpful to CEPS during their ABET accreditation cycle and we wish him all the success in that role. My office will establish a search process for this position and will announce that soon.

I'd like to end with some shout-outs this week. Congratulations to Dr. Amy Roberts, an associate professor in the School of Teacher Education, who is the recipient of a prestigious Fulbright-Hays Group Projects Abroad (GPA) grant to Costa Rica. Dr. Roberts is currently leading 11 Fulbright-Hays GPA program participants for eight weeks in Costa Rica. Finally, congratulations to the Shepard Symposium on Social Justice award winners for this year.  Thank you for all you do or have done at UW!

  • Zebadiah Hall
  • Courtney Titus
  • Allison Gernant
  • Winnie Wolfgang
  • Ryan O’Neil
  • Matthew Greenberg
  • Enrique (Enjo) Salonga
  • Katie Morgan
     

Enjoy the holiday and stay safe,   

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

As you recall, last year the Board of Trustees and the UW Foundation Board of Directors made a significant investment in faculty excellence. The Board of Trustees invested in a recruiting and retention quasi-endowment at the foundation to support faculty excellence—for example, the recently termed professorships we have been able to award.

The Foundation Board of Directors provided a $2.5 million matching fund to incentivize private gifts resulting in four new faculty endowments: the H. A. "Dave" True, Jr. Family College of Business Deanship, the Thomas and Shelley Botts Department Head in Civil Engineering, the John P. Ellbogen Foundation Professor of Early Childhood Education and the Donald L. Blackstone, Jr. Professorship in Geology.

During this year’s legislative session, the Wyoming Legislature provided $10 million for the University Endowment Challenge program to support student success and faculty excellence. The Board of Trustees also designated $5 million for faculty excellence.  We’re happy to report the Foundation major giving staff are having a great deal of success connecting donors with this matching program to create new endowed faculty positions. Look for additional reporting in the future, but we can share that we will soon have a new endowed professorship in Mechanical Engineering and an endowed county coordinator for Teton County Extension. A new non-endowed professorship at the Center for Blockchain and Digital Innovation is also forthcoming.  These are just a few of the incredible opportunities that our university, donors, and supporters in the state are investing in UW. A big thank you to the UW Foundation, as well as our faculty and deans that make these gifts a reality. 

Due to the hard work of faculty and staff in the College of Education and School of Computing, UW now offers three more 100% online bachelor’s degrees in elementary education, special education, and applied software development. Added to the listing of already available online and in-person programs, the opportunities to learn at UW continue to grow.  These online programs are targeted toward students who otherwise would not be able to attend UW due to existing obligations, responsibilities, or barriers. Our university impact and reach grows through these programs, and I’m excited for these new students to become a part of our community.

As I have reported previously, we have been working to finalize the job duties for a new Vice Provost position. This morning, I provided Deans and Vice Presidents with a description of the duties and have asked them to provide nominations for the position of Vice Provost for Access and Engagement (formerly titled Vice Provost for Faculty and Student Access, Opportunity, and Wellbeing) by July 1.  They will be implementing a process for seeking expressions of interest in their units. This position is open to all employees and is not limited to employees with academic appointments.  If you are interested in the position and/or want to learn more about it, please contact your Dean or Vice President. 

Finally, our search for the next Dean of the College of Health Sciences launched with the recruiting process this week. Our colleagues in CHS and Summit Search Solutions are busy sending out the word. If you would like to send this information along to colleagues you know, you can find the position profile here, and the application portal here. Thanks in advance for your help in recruiting top candidates.   

You may recall that the 2022 Wyoming legislature allocated funds to establish a Physician’s Assistant program at UW in the College of Health Sciences.  Next week three finalists for the inaugural Director for the PA program will be visiting campus.  This week I had the opportunity to visit with all three finalists via Zoom.  They are all very impressive and well qualified, which gives me optimism for a successful outcome to the search.

I will be tucked away at the cabin next week, so the next message from me will be in July. Have a great weekend and enjoy the warmer weather! 

Cheers,   

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

As part of our ongoing efforts to boost enrollment and enhance student success, we have been engaged in a robust discussion with LCCC to improve advising and enhance the transition experience for students who wish to attend UW.  We have made very solid progress toward implementing a co-advising and co-admission model that will provide entering students at LCCC with impactful advising that will put them on a clear path toward completing their associate’s degree and then moving seamlessly over the hill to pursue their bachelor’s degree at UW.  I’d like to thank ACES member Becky Despain for agreeing to serve as the inaugural advisor in this exciting program.

At this week’s Board of Trustees meeting, we received the green light to initiate an internal search for a Vice Provost for Access and Engagement.  This one-year position will be charged with transitioning critical functions that are currently managed in the Office of Diversity Equity and Inclusion.  We are finalizing the position description and expect to launch an internal search next week.

Zoology & Physiology Professor Matt Kauffman recently received the Aldo Leopold Award from the American Society of Mammalogists in recognition of his lifetime achievements in conserving mammals and their habitats.  This is very prestigious (E.O. Wilson was a former recipient) award and I congratulate Matt for his remarkable career. 

Tomorrow is Kaylin Brooks’ last day as Program Coordinator in my office.  She has been an incredible member of our AA team over the past couple of years and will be sorely missed.  We wish her well as she moves to Colorado Springs with her fiancé.  Please stop by Old Main 321 between 11-1 tomorrow (Friday) to wish Kaylin well.  

We are pleased to welcome Paige Anderson to the AA team.  She starts next week as an Administrative Associate and will fill the position previously held by Ariel Ivanoff.

Finally, I’d like to welcome our new Dean of the College of Law, Julie Hill to UW. Julie is in the process of moving to Wyoming and starting her role on June 28th. Please give her and her family and big welcome to our great community!  I also want to recognize and thank Klint Alexander for his ten years of service as dean and wish him well as he returns to the faculty. 

Cheers,  

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

We are close to finalizing a job description for the new Vice Provost for Faculty, Staff, and Student Access, Opportunity, and Wellness. We are having discussions with President Seidel, and will announce what the nomination process will look like soon. Stay tuned.

I was honored to meet the Consul General Prakash Gupta from India this past Tuesday during his visit to our beautiful campus. The discussion was incredibly useful and provided insight into how we can continue and improve our focus on international student recruitment. Our team will be following up on some of these ideas in the coming months. He is also interested in forging partnerships between UW and Indian universities in areas such as clean energy, agriculture, and tourism. I’d like to thank our Global Engagement team for coordinating a very full and informative visit.

On Wednesday of this week, our UW team met with LCCC colleagues to continue discussions on improving transfer student success. Our focus is on co-admissions, co-advising, program alignment, and shared data and systems. Our transfer student population is very important and I’m glad to see the collaboration and dedication of improving this process and educational experience for students.

Finally, colleagues, it is June, which means we celebrate Pride Month. Laramie Pridefest and student organizations are hosting these events this month to raise awareness and increase support for LGBTQIA+ students, faculty, staff, and community members. These events are open to the public, and I encourage you to join any of the events held in our community, among them being Laramie Pridefest, held June 7-15th. You can check out more about the events here.

My tomato planting this weekend went well, but not as well as the farewell celebration Susan and I hosted for VP Zebadiah Hall and his wife Leslie on Saturday evening. We had lots of fun, and I hope Zebadiah felt the appreciation of the community that has supported his work at UW. We wish him and Leslie well on their next journey.

Enjoy the weekend,  
 

 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

This week, with the help of VP Zebadiah Hall, we are completing an analysis of the various duties/responsibilities currently carried out by the Office of DEI, determining existing offices that may be able to carry out some of those tasks, and finalizing a job description for the new Vice Provost for Faculty, Staff, and Student Access, Opportunity, and Wellness. VP Hall has been incredibly helpful, and we are making good progress. I will continue to update you as this transition develops.

UW is part of an NSF-funder I-Corps Hub, led by North Dakota State University (NDSU).  This multi-year grant support training of current and future entrepreneurs in development and commercialization of technology-based business ideas.  The Hub is actively seeking and recruiting applicants for a special cohort organized and led by UW in the fall of 2024.  The program will last 4 weeks and be offered in-person and remotely.  Wyoming teams of one or more members are encouraged to apply. For questions or information, contact Ramsankar Veerakumar (rveeraku@uwyo.edu) or go here. 

I continue to meet weekly with the BAS Working Group that the Wyoming Community College Commission established last month. There have been excellent conversations about the future of BAS programs in Wyoming, and I appreciate the open dialogue with our colleagues.

Kudos to the Department of Visual Arts faculty and staff for receiving accreditation from the National Association of Schools of Art and Design.  The NASAD standards for accreditation are quite rigorous so this recognition is a major point of pride for UW.

I’m looking forward to planting my tomatoes this weekend!   

Cheers,  
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues, 

I have some important personnel updates this week.  

Following 35 years serving as a professor in the Division of Kinesiology and Health, with the last 10 years of service to the University as Sr. Vice Provost, Dr. Tami Benham-Deal has announced her retirement, effective February 5, 2025.  It is difficult to overstate the magnitude of Tami’s contributions to UW.  She has provided sage counsel that has touched and improved every corner of UW.  Personally, I simply can’t imagine how I could have navigated the past three years without Tami’s patient guidance and unflagging good humor.

I am seeking expressions of interest in the position of Vice Provost/Faculty Affairs.  Tenured faculty at the Professor rank are preferred.  The scope of duties include: 

  • Overseeing the management and administration of the university’s system for annual, reappointment, tenure, promotion, and fixed-term-rolling contract reviews, the preparation of reports for the UW Board of Trustees, and the analysis and reporting of data related to academic personnel.
  • Working collaboratively with Human Resources and other offices on campus regarding employment matters for academic personnel and serves as the lead on matters involving faculty leaves, compensation, and development.  
  • Serving as the Provost’s policy advisor on numerous matters related to academic personnel and the Division of Academic Affairs and providing guidance to academic administrators, faculty, and staff on regulations, policies, and processes involving academic personnel.
  • Providing leadership on other issues related to the advancement and growth of faculty and their concerns.   

The successful candidate will have the opportunity to shadow Sr. Vice Provost Benham-Deal throughout the fall semester.  Start date is January 2, 2025. Please send your expression of interest and CV to provost@uwyo.edu by June 18, 2024.   For more information, contact Mandy Gifford, Chief of Staff, mandyj@uwyo.edu.   

You may recall during the May meeting with the Board of Trustees, President Seidel announced the creation of a new Vice Provost position in response to recent DEI legislative actions. Our office is currently working on the position description and process for filling the Vice Provost for Faculty, Staff, and Student Access, Opportunity, and Wellbeing and we will update you as this develops. 

I'm pleased to announce the addition of Dr. Nevin Aiken to the Academic Affairs team. Nevin will be serving as a Special Assistant to the Provost for Experiential Education and will lead efforts for the next two years to enhance and expand experiential learning opportunities at UW, and to develop standards for fulfilling the proposed USP requirement for experiential education that is expected to launch in fall of 2026. You will be hearing more on this topic in the fall. Welcome to the team, Nevin! 

Speaking of experiential learning, this past spring, 10 of our students participated in UW's 2024 London semester, led by Dr. Jean Garrison. This program has been an important staple of UW, going back to 1984, and I'm very pleased it continues. I'd also like to thank our colleagues in Education Abroad for facilitating such rich opportunities for our students and faculty. 

Enjoy the long weekend! 
 

 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,  

With the culmination of commencement last week, you can feel the ease of summer creeping in. We had around 1400 students walk in our commencement ceremony on Saturday, and it was wonderful to shake hands with every one of them (though I confess that my arm was a bit sore!). On Sunday I traveled to Casper with President Seidel and several colleagues to participate in the UW Casper ceremony where approximately 75 students received their diplomas.  Congrats, graduates, and thank you to our faculty and staff who provide the education and support for all our students. 

Thanks in large part to a generous appropriation from the Legislature, UW’s GA stipend minimums will be increased significantly beginning this coming August.  The doctoral minimum stipend will jump from $17,838 to $21,762, while the master’s minimum will go from $12,825 to $15,642.  These 22% increases in our minimum GA stipends will make us competitive with many R1 universities, and, most importantly, will go a long way to addressing the serious gap that has existed between our GA stipends and increases in the cost of living for our students.  The legislature’s appropriation will allow UW to move all our unrestricted-funded GAs up to the new minimums.

I hope you have heard the buzz around the new exhibit at our UW American Heritage Center. If you are a Marvel fan, I urge you to head over to the AHC to check out the "Stan Lee, Beyond the Book" exhibit that is currently on display. There will be a ribbon-cutting ceremony this evening that I'm sure will be well-attended. We are lucky to have amazing colleagues who bring events and exhibits like this to Laramie. 

As you likely know from an earlier campus release today, Vice President Zebadiah Hall has accepted a position at Salisbury University. This has been a difficult time for UW, and I am deeply saddened to lose a tremendous colleague. We send Zebadiah our best wishes and will always consider him a Poke and dear friend. 

Regards, 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues, 

  

It’s May, and this week is filled with the Board of Trustee meeting, commencement, and many recognition events. 

The board has a full agenda with new degree proposals and critical items for discussion. Once again, there was a robust debate on DEI, with many people providing public testimony. Thank you to those who spoke with your honesty and sincerity. If you would like to watch the meeting, you can find the link here. 

I recently formed a committee to launch the search for the next Dean of the College of Health Sciences. We are working with Summit Search Solutions, will begin advertising the position next month, and will work to identify a strong candidate pool for on-campus interviews in next fall. I will keep you updated on the process and would like to thank our colleagues in the College of Health Sciences for their continued commitment to the college and the university. 

Last year, I reached out to a group of retired faculty to see if there would be interest in forming a Retired Faculty Association at UW. There was strong support, and we held another meeting with interested retired faculty last month to flush out some details. A big thank you to Narina Nunez and Eric Sandeen for stepping in as interim co-chairs to get this going. More to come!

As was done last year, we have launched an annual review of degree programs with low rates of completion and requested follow-up reports from deans on programs identified as having low-completion rates.  The relevant SAPP specifies that reports are due to my office within six months of notice, as such departments will have until November 1, 2024, to report on the program. The programs we have identified this year are: 

College of Agriculture, Life Sciences, and Natural Resources  

·    BS in Botany

·    MS in Botany

·    PhD in Botany

·    MS in Entomology

·    PhD in Entomology

·    MS in Soil Sciences

·    PhD in Soil Sciences

·    MA in Molecular Biology

·    MS in Molecular Biology

·    PhD in Molecular Biology

College of Arts and Sciences 

·    BA in Religious Studies

·    MA in Political Science

·    BA in Art History

College of Education 

·    MST in Mathematics

·    BA in Physics

·    MST in Physics

·    MS in Natural Science

·    MS in Natural Science-Middle Level Math

·    MS in Natural Science-Middle Level Science

·    MS in Natural Science-Natural Science Education

·    MST in Natural Science

·    MA in Educ-Educational Administration

·    MS in Educ-Educational Leadership

·    MS in Educ-Special Education

·    EdD in Educ-Educational Administration

·    EdD in Educ-Curriculum & Instruction

·    PhD in Educ-Curriculum & Instruction

College of Engineering and Physical Sciences 

·    BA in Chemistry

I’d like to thank outgoing Faculty Senate Chair, Bob Sprague, for his leadership this past year. I’ve enjoyed working with him and appreciated his demeanor, candor, humor, and collaboration on important topics. I also welcome incoming Chair, Ray Fertig. I look forward to working with you, Ray, and hope we can continue working on our common commitment to shared governance. 

Finally, the last faculty award I was honored to present this spring was to Sarah Lee in the Family and Consumer Sciences Department. Sarah was selected for the Hollon Award for Online Teaching Excellence. Congrats, Sarah, and to all of our awardees that we will be honoring this evening at the Commencement Dinner!

Sincerely, 
 

 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues, 

  

This has been a busy week of collaboration and travel. 

On Tuesday, I attended the Joint Labor, Health, & Social Services Committee meeting in Afton. There was a robust discussion on our WICHE, WWAMI and residency programs and was glad to be able to provide clarity and answer questions on these critical offerings. I'd like to thank Interim Dean Michelle Hilaire for her attendance and leadership during the discussion. 

Yesterday, I traveled to Cheyenne to engage in a wonderful discussion with our colleagues at Laramie County Community College on transfer student success. President Shaffer and his team were very gracious in hosting us, and we look forward to improving our collaborative processes to ensure transfer students come to UW with ease and transparency to pursue their chosen field of study. 

Today, I am in Fort Washakie attending the meeting of the Select Committee on Tribal Relations. Our discussion today is focusing on retention, graduation, and financial support for Native students.

I'd like to give a shout-out to the success of two student teams who participated in the Rocky Mountain Investment Challenge that was recently held at CSU.  Seniors in Finance Brentan Brown, Nick Walton, Tim Keely, Gus Mahieu along with juniors in Finance Maclean Hellyer, Karston Stone, Keaton Stone and sophomore in Finance Tim Siau.  The students comprised two teams that captured first and second place in the 18-team competition.  The competition included teams from the University of Michigan, Iowa State, CU, CSU, CU Denver, DU, Western Colorado, Utah State, and Utah Valley. Congrats, to our UW team!

Have you completed the FSSE? The Faculty Survey of Student Engagement (FSSE) closes May 13th - there is still time to complete the survey and reflect on perceptions and expectations regarding student learning and development at UW. To access your individualized survey link please search your inbox for "fsse@fsse.org" or "noreply@qualtrics-research.com." For additional information click here.

The Office of Student Success and Graduation is hosting the Readiness Rally this Friday from 11-5 in the Wyoming Union and Prexy's Pasture.  The purpose of the event is to increase student persistence at UW by eliminating or reducing barriers that impact a student’s ability to return for the fall semester.  The goal of the Rally is to provide students with direct, meaningful assistance that allows them to be confident that they are prepared to continue their UW education before they depart for the summer. Thank you to Dr. Nycole Courtney and her team for putting this together, and to all our colleagues who will be there to help students. 

A gentle reminder about this summer, and our procedures related to low-enrollment courses. All Department Heads/Chairs were sent a communication from Vice Provosts Jim Ahern and Steve Barrett outlining the enrollment minimums for summer courses, and the procedures for requesting a waiver. Thank you for your attention to this. 

Finally, I was honored to provide a lecture and participate in a discussion on leadership with LTC Paul Hanson's ROTC Senior class last week. These students are dedicated young scholars who will soon be engaged with critical leadership roles in service of our country. 


Sincerely, 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues,

If you weren’t able to attend in person or online to listen to the Buchanan Lecture with Dr. Katrina Zook, I would highly recommend you watch the recording, which can be found here.  Dr. Zook provided a wonderful lecture on the “Invisible Art of Teaching and Transformation”, in which she shared lessons to learn about teaching and interactions with students.  Thank you, Katrina—we appreciate your dedication to teaching and music and hope you enjoy retirement.

As I mentioned last week, I want to update you on the remaining Wyoming Community College meetings I attended last Thursday and Friday.  There was a robust discussion of expanding the offering of Bachelor of Applied Sciences degrees from our community college partners.  From that discussion, WCCC Chair Megan Overmann Goetz formed a BAS Exploratory Committee to review the BAS expansions.  I will be serving on the committee, which will meet weekly from April 30 through the end of May.  I will provide updates when the committee completes its deliberations. 

The University of Wyoming’s School of Graduate Education and Graduate Council have selected the 2024 winners of graduate student and mentor awards for outstanding teaching and research. Congratulations to all of the award winners and nominees this year! You can click here to read about the award recipients. Graduate students looking for a fellowship should consider applying for the Carlton R. Barkhurst Fellowship.  The fellowship is intended to help PhD and master’s candidates finish their dissertation/thesis in a timely manner. For more information about qualification requirements and application information, go here.  Please note that for Fall semester applications, they must be completed by June 30, 2024. 

As we approach the end of the semester, I’d like to remind our faculty colleagues about the importance of submitting your course material adoptions for the upcoming fall term. Fall adoptions are due tomorrow, Friday, April 26th. 

One more faculty award announcement this week: Dr. Kent Drummond was selected as the recipient of the John P. "Jack" Ellbogen Lifetime Teaching Award for 2024. I was able to surprise Kent at a Department of English faculty meeting to share the good news. 

Regards, 
 

Kevin C.
provost@uwyo.edu

Dear Colleagues, 

My letter this week may be a bit longer than usual, but there is lots to cover. 

It’s been a big week for UW, as our DEI Working Group submitted their report to President Seidel, and he has opened it up for public comment. This has been a challenging and difficult process that has very real implications.  I would be grateful if you would review the report and provide your feedback, as every voice deserves to be heard. You can view the message from President Seidel here. 

I was very pleased to attend the Staff Recognition Day, congratulate the winners of the staff awards, and to show my deep appreciation for our staff colleagues. I was also honored to see our Academic Affairs Program Coordinator, Kaylin Brooks, receive the Jodi K. Humphrey Inspirational Staff Award. If you have ever worked or communicated with Kaylin, you know why she deserved this award.

Congrats, Kaylin, and to all the award winners! 

A member of the committee that selects students for the Tobin Memorial Award and Rosemarie Spitaleri Award, which recognizes UW’s top undergraduate students, recently reached out to a group of faculty who were mentioned in the interview process as teaching classes that “changed their mind about an important issue”. These impactful faculty and their classes are: 

  • Nevin Aiken and Eric Nigh, Israeli & Palestinian Conflict
  • Dan Auerbach, Sociological Principles and Environmental Sociology
  • Joslyn Cassady, Inuit Environmental Dilemmas
  • Andrew Garner, American & Wyoming Government
  • Mark Gomelsky, Microbial Physiology
  • Michelle Jarman, Diverse Minds
  • Alexandra Kelly, Museology II
  • Kate Northrup, Writing Animals
  • Paul Taylor, Wyoming Walkabout
  • Clair Uding, Issues in Policing
  • Rachel Watson, Microbiology Capstone
  • Chemical Engineering Senior Design II

A big thank you to these faculty and all who are helping to guide students to be critical and thoughtful thinkers. I would also like to thank Maggie Bourque, for taking the time to write these faculty and let them know of the inspiration they provide.

Kudos to the UW College of Law, which name one of the top 8 schools for their Environmental Law program.  You can read about in this article here.  The College of Law was also recently recognized by preLaw magazine as a Best School for Practical Training.

As you know, each spring we collect nominations for various faculty awards. A big thanks to the Faculty Senate Committee on Faculty Recognition for going through the difficult task of recommending recipients of to be honored with these awards. For my part, I get the honor of attending faculty meetings and surprising these faculty with their awards. Here are a few photos from my visits this week:

Stay tuned next week for more award announcements!

I drove from Laramie this morning to Casper to attend the Wyoming Community College Commission meeting. It’s being hosted on the Casper College campus, which is always great to visit. There is plenty to cover on the agenda, which you can find here, and I look forward to sharing an update with you next week.  This afternoon the Commission and community college presidents engaged in a robust discussion regarding the possible expansion of BAS degrees.  I was pleased to be invited by Chair Megan Goetz to participate in this important discussion.  Nothing will be decided at this meeting, and we have been assured that UW will be included in future deliberations regarding BAS degrees.   

Kevin C.

Dear Colleagues, 

As you know, UW recently applied for and achieved the Carnegie Elective Classification for Community Engagement this past January, which you can read about here.  We were incredibly proud of the work that went into our application.  We recently were provided with feedback from the Carnegie Elective Classification for Community Engagement Team. The letter was brief, very positive, and complimentary.  In the few recommendations for improvement, it was suggested we would benefit from improved data collection and management, and a clearer recognition of engagement in our curriculum, both of which we acknowledged in our application.  I'm very pleased with the feedback and again, send thanks to the many colleagues who made this possible. 

I hope to see you at the UW Spring 2024 Convocation on Wednesday, April 24th from 2:30-4:30 pm in the Union Ballroom.  In addition to an address from President Seidel, you will hear from Faculty Senate, the UW Freedom of Expression Community of Practice, and others. 

Congratulations to Jaylan Alieve, Ph.D. student in Psychology, who was recently awarded an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, which recognizes and supports outstanding graduate students in STEM fields. It is an extremely competitive award, and she joins several other Ph.D. students in Psychology and Zoology & Physiology who received this award over the past couple of year.  It is worth noting that a large majority of scientists in the National Academy of Science received this award when they were graduate students…so stay tuned for even bigger things to come!  And one more shout out to our recent UW graduate Maeve Knepper, who was selected as one of the 2024 Donald M. Payne International Development Fellows. Maeve was one of only 30 students to receive this award out of 800 applicants.  And she is only the second UW student to ever receive this award.  This fellowship provides funding for graduate studies and a position in the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) Foreign Service after graduate school. I'm incredibly proud of our students and grateful for the support they receive from our faculty and staff as they pursue these awards and recognitions. 

I'm currently attending the annual WICHE Forum along with Jim Ahern who is wrapping up a year-long participation in the WICHE Leadership Academy.  The Forum is an annual gathering of chief academic officers (AKA provosts) from universities in WICHE states.  It is useful to cultivate relationships with my counterparts throughout the west and very helpful to share experiences on how we are dealing with common challenges that we are facing.

Susan and I will be on vacation next week so my next letter will be on April 18.

Regards,

Kevin C.

Dear Colleagues, 

Per the Standard Administrative Policy and Procedure: Academic Program Review, the Provost’s Office must annually review degree production for all academic programs. Thus, my team in AA has been looking over the data to review low-producing programs as we did last year.  Although the number of programs below the completion threshold is much smaller than last, it does look like there will be several programs that need to be reviewed.  Once the data is ready, we will send information to Deans, who will then have six months to provide a response. We will keep you informed and provide the list of programs for review once finalized.

Faculty, instructors, and graduate teaching assistance who teach one undergraduate course in AY 23/24 are invited to participate in the Faculty Survey of Student Engagement (FSSE).  The Office of Academic Affairs and the Ellbogen Center for Teaching and Learning (ECTL), invite you to lend your voice and participate - FSSE collects data related to instructional staff perceptions and expectations regarding student learning and development.  Invitations to the survey were emailed on March 26, and you can learn more here.

In my regular meeting with Dean Cass Kvenild today she told me about a couple of very nice recognitions that her Libraries team members have recently received.  Samantha Peter, Chair of UW Libraries Research & Instruction, received the 2024 Librarian Recognition Award, sponsored by the Library Instruction Round Table of the American Library Association Librarian. Samantha was honored for her contributions to the development, advancement, and support of information literacy and instruction, especially in the areas of instructional design and universal design for learning.  The winner of the 2024 UW Libraries Outstanding Staff Award is Tandi Valdez, who works as a Library Associate, Senior in Interlibrary Loan (ILL).  This year Tandi navigated changes in personnel, workflow, and systems in the ILL department. She demonstrated a commitment to outstanding customer service and was a welcoming presence to her new colleagues. She has worked at the UW Libraries for 37 years. Congrats and thank you to Sammy and Tandi!

I will be at the annual Western Interstate Commission for Higher Education (WICHE) forum meeting next week with about 60 other chief academic officers from WICHE states. I will look forward to sharing with you what we discuss.  

Let’s all go to the AA Friday night and cheer on the Cowgirls as they host South Dakota in the third round of the NIT! 

Kevin C. 

Dear Colleagues, 

As many of you know, there are several critical topics being discussed at the Board of Trustees meeting this week. Among them are low-producing programs being recommended for discontinuation, the staff organizational structure and upcoming changes, and the recent budget footnote from the Wyoming Legislature on diversity, equity and inclusion. I’d like to take a moment and say thank you to those who attended the meeting today to provide public comment, or just be here to show support for DEI. Also there was a tremendous turnout of students, faculty, and staff for the open discussion this afternoon. Thank you for your voice, it’s important and was heard.  If you would like to watch more of the BOT meeting, you can find it here. 

It's that time of the semester again when the Faculty Senate puts on its speaker series. This semester's presentation will be given by Professor of Philosophy Brad Rettler titled “Money for the Marginalized”. Focused on the use of Bitcoin and other Cryptocurrency as "Resistance money." The event will take place Tuesday, March 26th at 4:10pm in the Union Family Room and available via Wyocast here. 

The Donor Relations team at the UW Foundation is currently accepting nominations for the faculty stewardships awards. You can nominate a faculty member here and the due date for nominations is Monday, March 25th. 

Recently, Vice Provost Matt Griswold attended the Art Museum Juried Student Exhibit and presented Academic Affairs sponsored scholarships to Ahmad Ansari, Daisy Bentley, Kane Garrison, and Michael Stoll. The students had excellent art exhibits and we were proud to honor them with a scholarship. Congrats!

Enjoy the sun, it’s been a beautiful week, 


Kevin C.

Dear Colleagues, 

I was able to attend Staff Senate yesterday and always appreciate connecting with the Senators, providing updates, and answering questions. It was especially gratifying to hear their interest in and support of Saddle Up.  I know the Staff Senate is busy organizing this year's Staff Recognition Day (SRD), which is a great time to show up and say thank you to those who help make our institution better.  SRD will take place on Tuesday, April 16th from 11 am-1 pm in the Arena Auditorium and will no doubt be a great event! If you have the time to provide a service for staff, they are looking for faculty volunteers to serve food to staff members.  You can sign up for a 1- or 2-hour shift by reaching out to Christina McDonald at cmcdon19@uwyo.edu. 

I have a couple of shout-outs this week and will start by saying congratulations to Dr. Saman Aryana for being selected as a Fulbright U.S. Scholar for Australia for the 2024-2025 year.   Serving as a Fulbright Scholar is such an honor and brings prestige to our institution. Thank you for your contribution and congratulations, Dr. Aryana! 

Additionally, Dr. Jinke Tang was recently appointed to serve as a member of the Department of Energy's Basic Energy Sciences Advisory Committee for a 3-year term.  This committee provides advice and recommendations on scientific, technical, and programmatic issues relating to DOE's Basic Energy Sciences Program including materials sciences, chemistry, biosciences, geosciences, engineering, and underlying competencies such as computational sciences.  Another great honor, and thank you, Dr. Tang for your important service. 

Before we know it, spring commencement will be upon us.  If you are attending commencement on Saturday, May 11, and would like to order regalia, make sure you put the order in by March 22. You can find more information and links to order here. 

I know many colleagues will be taking time next week for March break, and some of us will remain on campus. Wherever you are, and whatever you might be doing, I hope you will enjoy it!

Brace yourselves for some snow this evening!

Sincerely, 

Kevin C.

Dear Colleagues, 

This weekly communication is a bit earlier in the day than usual, but I wanted to make sure to send a reminder for UW staff to attend the Town Hall hosted by President Seidel today at 1:00pm in the Union Family Room. I attended the Faculty Town Hall yesterday and was appreciative of the questions and discussion.  I look forward to the conversation with staff today. 

Last week, I sent a communication to the College of Health Sciences regarding the Interim Dean process. All faculty and staff in the college received an email announcing my recommendation for Interim Dean and a survey asking for their thoughts on the candidate. I’d like to thank everyone in Health Sciences who provided valuable input in the process so far.  We hope to be announcing an Interim Dean following the March meeting of the Board of Trustees. 

The John P. Ellbogen Summer Institute is set for May 15-17, and the deadline to apply is quickly approaching. Participants will meet with teachers from different disciplines, engage in highly interactive discussions, share successful teaching strategies and innovations, seek solutions to their own teaching problems and challenges, and much more. You can view more about the summer institute and how to apply here. Applications are due by Friday, March 8th. 

Finally, I’d like to take a moment to express my deep sorrow with the loss of 4 students in the past couple of weeks. It’s never easy losing lives, and especially when they are young. Our thoughts are also with the two young men who survived the crash on 287.  I will close this letter by taking a moment of silence in honor of those we lost: 

Charlie Clark 

Sabrina Geller 

Carson Muir

Luke Slabber

Sincerely, 

Kevin C.

Dear Colleagues, 

As you may know, the 67th Legislative Session commenced last week, and items are being discussed that may impact our university. Please know that we have great UW representation at the session with Vice President Mike Smith. Although the legislative landscape is fluid and will likely continue to be so until the session ends, Mike is doing a great job of keeping President Seidel’s leadership team informed and engaged. If you would like to know more about the legislation this session, you can view it by viewing this website. 

Next Wednesday, President Seidel will be hosting a Faculty Town Hall at noon in the Union Family Room. This is a great opportunity to hear directly from you, the faculty, and I hope to see many of you there. If you'd like, you can join via WyoCast. 

President Seidel has formally charged a group to work on the physical, environmental, occupational, and psychological safety of our campus. The Campus Safety Working Group will officially convene tomorrow, and is co-chaired by myself, Vice President Parag Chitnis, and Vice President Bill Mai. Our task is to evaluate the mentioned aspects of campus safety and make recommendations and decisions that promote the safety of our UW community. I know these issues are important to you, and I pledge that we will make good progress on this. 

Susan and I enjoyed watching the Cowgirls do battle with the Mountain West’s #1 team, UNLV, in the AA last night.  The overtime loss was heartbreaking, but we should all be very proud of their great effort and their ongoing success during the 2023-24 campaign.

Until next week, stay safe and warm!

Kevin C.

Dear Colleagues, 

I recently met with representatives from Laramie County Community College to discuss how we can continue to build on the relationship and work to improve student success in transfer, advising, and registration between institutions. These conversations are very beneficial toward advancing our partnership with LCCC.  I'm grateful our LCCC colleagues took the time to drive over the hill (on a snowy day…) and meet with our team. If you didn't know, transfer students make up around 40% of our student population, so having a streamlined process and good working relationships with our community colleges is key. Tomorrow I am attending the Wyoming Community College Commission meeting in Cheyenne (weather permitting) and look forward to more conversations on collaborative efforts and moving forward together with Wyoming’s community colleges. 

A week ago you received an email from IT about an important change coming for accessing the UW network from home or while traveling.  IT is upgrading to “Duo Verified Push”. Beginning March 18th you’ll need to input a 6-digit code into your smartphone’s Duo app for access. Receiving a phone call for access will be discontinued. If you are using the phone call option you will need to get the smartphone Duo app or obtain a YubiKey.  IT can assist you with either.  Contact the IT Help Desk, at 307-766-HELP or email userhelp@uwyo.edu.

As everyone knows, the incredible staff we have at UW are essential to faculty and student success, and we simply couldn’t function without them.  If you would like to recognize an outstanding staff member, consider nominating them for one of the many awards provided during the annual Staff Recognition Day on April 16, 11-1 at the Arena Auditorium.  You can find a link to nominate a staff member by visiting this website. I look forward to this event, and I hope to see many of you there supporting those who support us. 

I am meeting this week with faculty and staff in the individual units within the College of Health Sciences to get input on the transition in leadership in the college.  I have thus far met with Social Work, Nursing, Pharmacy, and WIND.  I have been truly inspired by the collegiality, thoughtful reflections, and optimism that I have heard thus far.  I expect to announce a recommended Interim Dean next week and will seek additional feedback from the college before bringing my final recommendation to the Board of Trustees for approval in March.

It is February, which means we celebrate Black History Month. I'm very pleased to see the many offerings through Multicultural Affairs and the Office of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion. Thank you to the many colleagues who are making these events and discussions happen on campus. You can find more about the schedule of events. 

Regards, 

Kevin C.
 

 
 

Dear Colleagues, 

It's one of the best times of the year when we honor incredible colleagues with the multiple awards available at UW. 

Nominations for our annual faculty awards are currently being solicited with a deadline of February 19th. The Ellbogen, Humphrey, Hollon, and Laramigo awards are a great way to show deep appreciation for the work of our colleagues. You can view more about the process by visiting this website. I'd like to thank the Faculty Senate Recognition Committee for their dedication and time in reviewing the nomination packets and recommending faculty for these awards. A special shout-out to those Faculty Recognition Committee members:

  • Sandy Hsu
  • Macenzie Festa
  • Courtney McKim (Chair)
  • Nancy Peck
  • Jeremy Vandiver
  • Noah Novogrodsky
  • Samantha Peter
  • Li Li
  • Jeff Miller

The nomination deadline for Faculty and Student Awards for Graduate Education is Feb. 16, 2024, at 5 p.m. The Graduate Council will review nominations and select the awardees. You can find information describing the awards and the nominating procedures by viewing this pdf. Each award carries a stipend. Please send nominations, including all letters and supporting materials, electronically, to Sarah Wolverton, swolver1@uwyo.edu.

Over the past few months, I've been meet with department heads/chairs across campus. I have thoroughly enjoyed the informal discussions and opportunities to meet with campus leaders in their spaces and learn more about their goals and challenges. Since November of last year, I've met with over 25 heads/chairs, and I look forward to meeting several more who are on my schedule in coming weeks.  Serving as a department chair/head is arguably the most challenging and important leadership role on campus.  I take great comfort in knowing that we have such a strong and dedicated group of individuals who are leading UW’s academic departments.  If you are a chair/head who hasn't scheduled to meet with me and would like to do so, please contact Kaylin Brooks in my office to set that up. 

Regards,

Kevin C.

Dear Colleagues, 

This semester, the Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion is hosting gatherings for faculty to discuss equitable faculty workloads with fellow colleagues. These sessions will be led by Vice President for ODEI, Zebadiah Hall and are meant to be an informal and safe space to share personal thoughts on workloads while also having a chance to gain insight on other's opinions.  Multiple session dates and times are offered.  You can sign up for a session by visiting website.  If you have any questions, please contact Kaylin Brooks at kbrooks19@uwyo.edu or call our office at (307) 766-4286.

The AI committee needs to hear from you on what AI tools you’re using for your own productivity and for teaching and learning, as well as how comfortable you are with using generative AI. Here’s a link to the survey they’ve launched to gather your feedback – this will help them understand the landscape and formulate recommendations to me about where we should be investing resources and time in generative AI tools.

Vice Provost Matt Griswold and team have been working hard across campus to increase the availability of fully online bachelor’s degree programs for online education students. Programs available include accounting, criminal justice, human resources concentration in management, management, marketing, organizational leadership, and sociology (you can view the programs by visiting this webpage).  There will also be wider access to the general studies degree.  More online degrees are coming.  These degrees are a great avenue for UW to connect to students across Wyoming, the country, and internationally.  I would like to thank Matt, his team, and all our colleagues who have worked to offer these opportunities. 

Finally, just a reminder about nominations for the Tobin Memorial and Rosemarie Martha Spitaleri Outstanding Undergraduate Awards. Criteria for these awards include academic excellence and achievement, contributions and service to the University of Wyoming, active participation and leadership in co-curricular activities, and demonstrated good character and citizenship. Nomination letters are due by Friday, February 9, 2024.  Please direct questions to studentaffairs@uwyo.edu or call (307) 766-5123 for further assistance. For more information on these awards, please see the Student Affairs webpage.

Regards,

Kevin C.

Dear Colleagues,

The Board of Trustees is in session this week, if you would like to tune in for the public session discussions, you can view the meeting by visiting the webpage.

We have been keeping up with the ever-changing world of Artificial Intelligence through the AI Working Group that was officially formed on November 1, 2023.  The group has designed an AI resources site you can find by visiting webpage that provides updates on the committee work, upcoming events including a link to register for an AI Training event hosted by ECTL.  More to come on this topic, and a big thank you to the working group.

This spring, work will continue with Phase III of the Next Generation University Studies Program.  Co-chaired by Mandy Gifford, Chief of Staff to the Provost, and Dr. Morteza Dejam, Associate Professor in Energy and Petroleum Engineering, a group of Next Generation Education Fellows will chair subcommittees to work on the components of the new draft model, which you can view the pdf.  The subcommittees will be charged with developing definitions of the components, student learning outcomes, and policy recommendations.
